segments.content: Introduction As most programmers know, Python has a Global InterpreterLock(GIL) Itimposes various restrictions on threads ●Namely,you can't utilize multipleCPUs Thus, it's a (frankly) tired subject for flamewars  about how Python"sucks" (along with tail-call optimization,lambda,whitespace,etc.) 3

Thus, it's a (frankly) tired subject for flamewars

segments.html: Introduction As most programmers know, Python has a Global InterpreterLock(GIL) Itimposes various restrictions on threads ●Namely,you can't utilize multipleCPUs Thus, it's a (frankly) tired subject for flamewars about how Python"sucks" (along with tail-call optimization,lambda,whitespace,etc.) 3

segments.content: Disclaimers
segments.html: Disclaimers
segments.markdown: ## Disclaimers

segments.content: • Python's use of a GIL doesn't bother me
segments.html: • Python's use of a GIL doesn't bother me
segments.markdown: - Python's use of a GIL doesn't bother me

segments.content: • I don't have strong feelings about it either way
segments.html: • I don't have strong feelings about it either way
segments.markdown: - I don't have strong feelings about it either way

segments.content: • Bias : For parallel computing involving heavy CPU processing, I much prefer message passing and cooperating processes to thread programming (of course, it depends on the problem)
segments.html: • Bias : For parallel computing involving heavy CPU processing, I much prefer message passing and cooperating processes to thread programming (of course, it depends on the problem)
segments.markdown: - Bias : For parallel computing involving heavy CPU processing, I much prefer message passing and cooperating processes to thread programming (of course, it depends on the problem)

segments.content: • However, the GIL has some pretty surprising behavior on multicore that interests me
segments.html: • However, the GIL has some pretty surprising behavior on multicore that interests me
segments.markdown: - However, the GIL has some pretty surprising behavior on multicore that interests me

segments.content: A Mystery
segments.html: A Mystery
segments.markdown: ## A Mystery

segments.content: • Why do I get these performance results on my Dual-Core MacBook? Sequential    : 24.6s Threaded     : 45.5s  (1.8X slower!)
segments.html: • Why do I get these performance results on my Dual-Core MacBook? Sequential : 24.6s Threaded : 45.5s (1.8X slower!)
segments.markdown: - Why do I get these performance results on my Dual-Core MacBook? Sequential    : 24.6s Threaded     : 45.5s  (1.8X slower!)

segments.content: • And if I disable one of the CPU cores, why does the threaded performance get better? Threaded     : 38.0s
segments.html: • And if I disable one of the CPU cores, why does the threaded performance get better? Threaded : 38.0s
segments.markdown: - And if I disable one of the CPU cores, why does the threaded performance get better? Threaded     : 38.0s

segments.content: • Think about that for a minute... Bloody hell!

segments.markdown: - Think about that for a minute... Bloody hell!

segments.content: Overview
segments.html: Overview
segments.markdown: ## Overview

segments.content: • I don't like unexplained mysteries or magic
segments.html: • I don't like unexplained mysteries or magic
segments.markdown: - I don't like unexplained mysteries or magic

segments.content: • As part of a workshop I ran in May, I went digging into the GIL implementation to see if I could figure out exactly why I was getting those performance results
segments.html: • As part of a workshop I ran in May, I went digging into the GIL implementation to see if I could figure out exactly why I was getting those performance results

segments.content: What is a Thread?
segments.html: What is a Thread?
segments.markdown: ## What is a Thread?

segments.content: • Python threads are real system threads
segments.html: • Python threads are real system threads
segments.markdown: - Python threads are real system threads

segments.content: • POSIX threads (pthreads)
segments.html: • POSIX threads (pthreads)
segments.markdown: - POSIX threads (pthreads)

segments.content: • Windows threads
segments.html: • Windows threads
segments.markdown: - Windows threads

segments.content: • Fully managed by the host operating system
segments.html: • Fully managed by the host operating system
segments.markdown: - Fully managed by the host operating system

segments.content: • All scheduling/thread switching
segments.html: • All scheduling/thread switching
segments.markdown: - All scheduling/thread switching

segments.content: • Represent threaded execution of the Python interpreter process (written in C)
segments.html: • Represent threaded execution of the Python interpreter process (written in C)
segments.markdown: - Represent threaded execution of the Python interpreter process (written in C)

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Thread Creation • Python threads simply execute a "callable" • The run() method of Thread (or a function) 9 import time import threading class CountdownThread(threading.Thread): def __init__(self,count): threading.Thread.__init__(self) self.count = count def run(self): while self.count > 0: print "Counting down", self.count self.count -= 1 time.sleep(5) return
segments.html: • Copyright (C) 2009, David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Thread Creation • Python threads simply execute a "callable" • The run() method of Thread (or a function) 9 import time import threading class CountdownThread(threading.Thread): def __init__(self,count): threading.Thread.__init__(self) self.count = count def run(self): while self.count > 0: print "Counting down", self.count self.count -= 1 time.sleep(5) return
segments.markdown: - Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Thread Creation • Python threads simply execute a "callable" • The run() method of Thread (or a function) 9 import time import threading class CountdownThread(threading.Thread): def __init__(self,count): threading.Thread.__init__(self) self.count = count def run(self): while self.count > 0: print "Counting down", self.count self.count -= 1 time.sleep(5) return

segments.content: • Python creates a small data structure containing some interpreter state
segments.html: • Python creates a small data structure containing some interpreter state
segments.markdown: - Python creates a small data structure containing some interpreter state

segments.content: • A new thread (pthread) is launched
segments.html: • A new thread (pthread) is launched

segments.content: • The thread calls PyEval_CallObject
segments.html: • The thread calls PyEval_CallObject
segments.markdown: - The thread calls PyEval_CallObject

segments.content: • Last step is just a C function call that runs whatever Python callable was specified
segments.html: • Last step is just a C function call that runs whatever Python callable was specified
segments.markdown: - Last step is just a C function call that runs whatever Python callable was specified

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Thread-Specific State • Each thread has its own interpreter specific data structure (PyThreadState) • Current stack frame (for Python code) • Current recursion depth • Thread ID • Some per-thread exception information • Optional tracing/profiling/debugging hooks • It's a small C structure (<100 bytes) 11

segments.content: The Infamous GIL
segments.html: The Infamous GIL
segments.markdown: ## The Infamous GIL

segments.content: • Here's the rub...
segments.html: • Here's the rub...
segments.markdown: - Here's the rub...

segments.content: • Only one Python thread can execute in the interpreter at once
segments.html: • Only one Python thread can execute in the interpreter at once
segments.markdown: - Only one Python thread can execute in the interpreter at once

segments.content: • There is a "global interpreter lock" that carefully controls thread execution
segments.html: • There is a "global interpreter lock" that carefully controls thread execution
segments.markdown: - There is a "global interpreter lock" that carefully controls thread execution

segments.content: • The GIL ensures that sure each thread gets exclusive access to the interpreter internals when it's running (and that call-outs to C extensions play nice)
segments.html: • The GIL ensures that sure each thread gets exclusive access to the interpreter internals when it's running (and that call-outs to C extensions play nice)
segments.markdown: - The GIL ensures that sure each thread gets exclusive access to the interpreter internals when it's running (and that call-outs to C extensions play nice)

segments.content: GIL Behavior It's simple :threads hold the GlL when running However, they release it when blocking for I/O run run 1/O run 1/O run 1/O elease cquire C release- acquire release acquire- So, any time a thread is forced to wait, other "ready" threads get their chance to run Basically akind of "cooperative"multitasking 15 Copyright（C） 2009,David Beazle /www.dabeaz.com

ocr.text: It's simple :threads hold the GlL when running
However, they release it when blocking for I/O
So, any time a thread is forced to wait, other
"ready" threads get their chance to run

segments.html: GIL Behavior It's simple :threads hold the GlL when running However, they release it when blocking for I/O run run 1/O run 1/O run 1/O elease cquire C release- acquire release acquire- So, any time a thread is forced to wait, other "ready" threads get their chance to run Basically akind of "cooperative"multitasking 15 Copyright（C） 2009,David Beazle /www.dabeaz.com

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com CPU Bound Processing • To deal with CPU-bound threads that never perform any I/O, the interpreter periodically performs a "check" • By default, every 100 interpreter "ticks" 16 CPU Bound Thread Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks check check check • sys.setcheckinterval() changes the setting
segments.html: • Copyright (C) 2009, David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com CPU Bound Processing • To deal with CPU-bound threads that never perform any I/O, the interpreter periodically performs a "check" • By default, every 100 interpreter "ticks" 16 CPU Bound Thread Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks check check check • sys.setcheckinterval() changes the setting
segments.markdown: - Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com CPU Bound Processing • To deal with CPU-bound threads that never perform any I/O, the interpreter periodically performs a "check" • By default, every 100 interpreter "ticks" 16 CPU Bound Thread Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks Run 100 ticks check check check • sys.setcheckinterval() changes the setting

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com The Check Interval • The check interval is a global counter that is completely independent of thread scheduling 17 Main Thread 100 ticks check check check 100 ticks 100 ticks Thread 2 Thread 3 Thread 4 100 ticks • A "check" is simply made every 100 "ticks"
segments.html: Copyright (C) 2009, David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com The Check Interval • The check interval is a global counter that is completely independent of thread scheduling 17 Main Thread 100 ticks check check check 100 ticks 100 ticks Thread 2 Thread 3 Thread 4 100 ticks • A "check" is simply made every 100 "ticks"
segments.markdown: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com The Check Interval • The check interval is a global counter that is completely independent of thread scheduling 17 Main Thread 100 ticks check check check 100 ticks 100 ticks Thread 2 Thread 3 Thread 4 100 ticks • A "check" is simply made every 100 "ticks"

segments.content: The Periodic Check What happens during the periodic check? In the main thread only, signal handlers will execute if there are any pending signals (more shortly) Release and reacquire the GIL Thatlast bullet describeshow multiple CPU- bound threads get to run (by briefly releasing the GlL, other threads get a chance to run). 18

will execute if there are any pending
bound threads get to run (by briefly releasing
the GlL, other threads get a chance to run).

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com ceval.c execution /* Python/ceval.c */ ... if (--_Py_Ticker < 0) { ... _Py_Ticker = _Py_CheckInterval; ... if (things_to_do) { if (Py_MakePendingCalls() < 0) { ... } } if (interpreter_lock) { /* Give another thread a chance */ ... PyThread_release_lock(interpreter_lock); /* Other threads may run now */ PyThread_acquire_lock(interpreter_lock, 1); ... }

PyThread_release_lock(interpreter_lock); /* Other threads may run now */ PyThread_acquire_lock(interpreter_lock, 1); ... }

PyThread_release_lock(interpreter_lock); /* Other threads may run now */ PyThread_acquire_lock(interpreter_lock, 1); ... }

segments.content: What is a "Tick? Ticks loosely map to interpreter instructions >>> import dis defcountdown（n): >>> dis.dis（countdown) while n> 0： 0 SETUPLOOP 33（to36） printn 3 LOAD FAST o（n） n 1 6LOAD CONST 1（0） 9 COMPAREOP 4（>） Instructionsin Tick1 12JUMP IF FALSE 19（to34） 15POP TOP thePythonVM 16LOAD FAST 0（n） 19PRINT ITEM Tick2 20PRINT NEWLINE 21 LOAD FAST o（n） Tick3 24LOAD CONST 2（1） 27INPLACE SUBTRACT 28STORE FAST 0（n） Tick4 31 JUMP ABSOLUTE 3 20

segments.content: Tick Execution Interpreter ticks are not time-based In fact, long operations can block everything num xrange（100000000） >>> -1in nums tick（~6.6seconds） False > Try hitting Ctrl-C (ticks are uninterruptible) nums xrange（100000000） >>> -1 in nums ^C^C^C （nothinghappens,long pause) KeyboardInterrupt

ocr.text: In fact, long operations can block everything

segments.content: Interlude : Signals Let's briefly talk about Ctrl-C A very common problem encountered with Python thread programming is that threaded programs can nolonger be killed with the keyboardinterrupt It is EXTREMELY ANNOYING (you have to use kill-9 in a separate window) Everwonder why it doesn'twork? 22

segments.html: Interlude : Signals Let's briefly talk about Ctrl-C A very common problem encountered with Python thread programming is that threaded programs can nolonger be killed with the keyboardinterrupt It is EXTREMELY ANNOYING (you have to use kill-9 in a separate window) Everwonder why it doesn'twork? 22

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Signal Handling • If a signal arrives, the interpreter runs the "check" after every tick until the main thread runs 23 Main Thread 100 ticks check Thread 2 Thread 3 • Since signal handlers can only run in the main thread, the interpreter quickly acquires/releases the GIL after every tick until it gets scheduled check SIGNAL checkcheck 1 tick 100 ticks checkcheckcheck signal handler
segments.html: • Copyright (C) 2009, David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Signal Handling • If a signal arrives, the interpreter runs the "check" after every tick until the main thread runs 23 Main Thread 100 ticks check Thread 2 Thread 3 • Since signal handlers can only run in the main thread, the interpreter quickly acquires/releases the GIL after every tick until it gets scheduled check SIGNAL checkcheck 1 tick 100 ticks checkcheckcheck signal handler
segments.markdown: - Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Signal Handling • If a signal arrives, the interpreter runs the "check" after every tick until the main thread runs 23 Main Thread 100 ticks check Thread 2 Thread 3 • Since signal handlers can only run in the main thread, the interpreter quickly acquires/releases the GIL after every tick until it gets scheduled check SIGNAL checkcheck 1 tick 100 ticks checkcheckcheck signal handler

segments.content: Thread Scheduling
segments.html: Thread Scheduling
segments.markdown: ## Thread Scheduling

segments.content: • Python does not have a thread scheduler
segments.html: • Python does not have a thread scheduler
segments.markdown: - Python does not have a thread scheduler

segments.content: • There is no notion of thread priorities, preemption, round-robin scheduling, etc.
segments.html: • There is no notion of thread priorities, preemption, round-robin scheduling, etc.
segments.markdown: - There is no notion of thread priorities, preemption, round-robin scheduling, etc.

segments.content: • All thread scheduling is left to the host operating system (e.g., Linux, Windows, etc.)
segments.html: • All thread scheduling is left to the host operating system (e.g., Linux, Windows, etc.)
segments.markdown: - All thread scheduling is left to the host operating system (e.g., Linux, Windows, etc.)

segments.content: • This is partly why signals get so weird (the interpreter has no control over scheduling so it just attempts to thread switch as fast as possible with the hope that main will run)
segments.html: • This is partly why signals get so weird (the interpreter has no control over scheduling so it just attempts to thread switch as fast as possible with the hope that main will run)
segments.markdown: - This is partly why signals get so weird (the interpreter has no control over scheduling so it just attempts to thread switch as fast as possible with the hope that main will run)

segments.content: Frozen Signals
segments.html: Frozen Signals
segments.markdown: ## Frozen Signals

segments.content: • The reason Ctrl-C doesn't work with threaded programs is that the main thread is often blocked on an uninterruptible thread-join or lock
segments.html: • The reason Ctrl-C doesn't work with threaded programs is that the main thread is often blocked on an uninterruptible thread-join or lock
segments.markdown: - The reason Ctrl-C doesn't work with threaded programs is that the main thread is often blocked on an uninterruptible thread-join or lock

segments.content: • Since it's blocked, it never gets scheduled to run any kind of signal handler for it
segments.html: • Since it's blocked, it never gets scheduled to run any kind of signal handler for it
segments.markdown: - Since it's blocked, it never gets scheduled to run any kind of signal handler for it

segments.content: • And as an extra little bonus, the interpreter is left in a state where it tries to thread-switch after every tick (so not only can you not interrupt your program, it runs slow as hell!)
segments.html: • And as an extra little bonus, the interpreter is left in a state where it tries to thread-switch after every tick (so not only can you not interrupt your program, it runs slow as hell!)
segments.markdown: - And as an extra little bonus, the interpreter is left in a state where it tries to thread-switch after every tick (so not only can you not interrupt your program, it runs slow as hell!)

segments.content: GIL Implementation
segments.html: GIL Implementation
segments.markdown: ## GIL Implementation

segments.content: • The GIL is not a simple mutex lock
segments.html: • The GIL is not a simple mutex lock
segments.markdown: - The GIL is not a simple mutex lock

segments.content: • The implementation (Unix) is either...
segments.html: • The implementation (Unix) is either...
segments.markdown: - The implementation (Unix) is either...

segments.content: • A POSIX unnamed semaphore
segments.html: • A POSIX unnamed semaphore
segments.markdown: - A POSIX unnamed semaphore

segments.content: • Or a pthreads condition variable
segments.html: • Or a pthreads condition variable
segments.markdown: - Or a pthreads condition variable

segments.content: • All interpreter locking is based on signaling
segments.html: • All interpreter locking is based on signaling
segments.markdown: - All interpreter locking is based on signaling

segments.content: • To acquire the GIL, check if it's free. If not, go to sleep and wait for a signal
segments.html: • To acquire the GIL, check if it's free. If not, go to sleep and wait for a signal
segments.markdown: - To acquire the GIL, check if it's free. If not, go to sleep and wait for a signal

segments.content: • To release the GIL, free it and signal
segments.html: • To release the GIL, free it and signal
segments.markdown: - To release the GIL, free it and signal

segments.content: Thread Scheduling
segments.html: Thread Scheduling
segments.markdown: ## Thread Scheduling

segments.content: • The OS is just going to schedule whichever thread has the highest execution "priority"
segments.html: • The OS is just going to schedule whichever thread has the highest execution "priority"
segments.markdown: - The OS is just going to schedule whichever thread has the highest execution "priority"

segments.content: • CPU-bound : low priority
segments.html: • CPU-bound : low priority
segments.markdown: - CPU-bound : low priority

segments.content: • I/O bound : high priority
segments.html: • I/O bound : high priority
segments.markdown: - I/O bound : high priority

segments.content: • If a signal is sent to a thread with low priority and the CPUs are busy with higher priority tasks, it won't run until some later point
segments.html: • If a signal is sent to a thread with low priority and the CPUs are busy with higher priority tasks, it won't run until some later point
segments.markdown: - If a signal is sent to a thread with low priority and the CPUs are busy with higher priority tasks, it won't run until some later point

segments.content: • Read an OS textbook for details
segments.html: • Read an OS textbook for details
segments.markdown: - Read an OS textbook for details

segments.content: CPU-BoundThreads As we saw earlier, CPU-bound threads have horrible performanceproperties Far worse than simple sequential execution 24.6 seconds (sequential) 45.5 seconds (2 threads) A big question :Why? What is the source of that overhead? 29

segments.content: Signaling Overhead GIL thread signaling is the source of that ●After every I00 ticks,the interpreter Locksa mutex Signals on a condition variable/semaphore where another thread is always waiting Because another thread is waiting,extra pthreads processing and system calls get triggered to deliver the signal

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com A Rough Measurement • Sequential Execution (OS-X, 1 CPU) • 736 Unix system calls • 117 Mach System Calls • Two CPU-bound threads (OS-X, 1 CPU) • 1149 Unix system calls • ~ 3.3 Million Mach System Calls • Yow! Look at that last figure. 31

segments.content: An Experiment I did some instrumentation of the Python interpreter to look into this a little deeper Recorded a real-time trace of all GIL  acquisitions,releases, conflicts, retries,etc. Trying to get an idea of what the interpreter is doing,what different threads are doing interactions between threads and the GlL,and the overall sequencing of events 33 Copyright （C）2009.David Beazle

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Multicore GIL Contention • With multiple cores, CPU-bound threads get scheduled simultaneously (on different cores) and then have a GIL battle 35 Thread 1 (CPU 1) Thread 2 (CPU 2) Release GIL signal Acquire GIL Wake Acquire GIL (fails) Release GIL Acquire GIL signal Wake Acquire GIL (fails) run run run • The waiting thread (T2) may make 100s of failed GIL acquisitions before any success
segments.html: • Copyright (C) 2009, David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Multicore GIL Contention • With multiple cores, CPU-bound threads get scheduled simultaneously (on different cores) and then have a GIL battle 35 Thread 1 (CPU 1) Thread 2 (CPU 2) Release GIL signal Acquire GIL Wake Acquire GIL (fails) Release GIL Acquire GIL signal Wake Acquire GIL (fails) run run run • The waiting thread (T2) may make 100s of failed GIL acquisitions before any success
segments.markdown: - Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com Multicore GIL Contention • With multiple cores, CPU-bound threads get scheduled simultaneously (on different cores) and then have a GIL battle 35 Thread 1 (CPU 1) Thread 2 (CPU 2) Release GIL signal Acquire GIL Wake Acquire GIL (fails) Release GIL Acquire GIL signal Wake Acquire GIL (fails) run run run • The waiting thread (T2) may make 100s of failed GIL acquisitions before any success

segments.content: Copyright (C) 2009,  David Beazley, http://www.dabeaz.com The GIL Battle (Traced) 36 t2 100 5392 ENTRY t2 100 5392 ACQUIRE t2 100 5393 RELEASE t1 100 5393 ACQUIRE t2 100 5393 ENTRY t2  27 5393 BUSY t1 100 5394 RELEASE t1 100 5394 ENTRY t1 100 5394 ACQUIRE t2  74 5394 RETRY t1 100 5395 RELEASE t1 100 5395 ENTRY t1 100 5395 ACQUIRE t2  83 5395 RETRY t1 100 5396 RELEASE t1 100 5396 ENTRY t1 100 5396 ACQUIRE t2  80 5396 RETRY t1 100 5397 RELEASE t1 100 5397 ENTRY t1 100 5397 ACQUIRE t2  79 5397 RETRY ... A thread switch t2 tries to keep running, but immediately has to block because t1 acquired the GIL signal signal signal signal Here, the GIL battle begins.  Every RELEASE of the GIL signals t2.  Since there are two cores, the OS schedules t2, but leaves t1 running on the other core.  Since t1 is left running, it immediately reacquires the GIL before t2 can get to it (so, t2 wakes up, finds the GIL is in use, and blocks again)

Since there are two cores, the OS schedules t2, but leaves t1 running on the other core. Since t1 is left running, it immediately reacquires the GIL before t2 can get to it (so, t2 wakes up, finds the GIL is in use, and blocks again)

segments.content: A Scheduler Conflict ●What's happening here is that you're seeing a battle between two competing（and ultimatelyincompatible)goals Python - only wants to run single-  threaded,but doesn't want anything to do with thread scheduling (up to OS) OS-"Oooh.Multiplecores."Freely schedules processes/threads to take advantage of as many cores as possible

advantage of as many cores as possible

segments.content: Priority Inversion This last scenario is a bizarre sort of "priorityinversion"problem A CPU-bound thread(low priority)is blocking the execution of an I/O-bound thread (highpriority) It occurs because the I/O thread can't wake up fast enough to acquirethe GIL before the CPU-bound thread reacquires it And it only happens on multicore... 41 C2008

It occurs because the I/O thread can't

before the CPU-bound thread reacquires it

segments.content: Comments ●As far as I can tell, the Python GIL implementation has not changed much (if at all) inthe last IOyears The GlL code in Python I.5.2 looks almost identical to the code in Python 3.0 ●I don't know whether it's even been studied all that much (especially on multicore) There is more interest in removing the GIL than simply changing the GIL

segments.content: Comments Ithink this deserves further study There is a pretty severe performance penalty for using threads on multicore Thepriority inversion forI/O-bound processing is somewhat disturbing Probably worth fixing--especially if the GIL is going to stick around 43

segments.content: Open Questions
segments.html: Open Questions
segments.markdown: ## Open Questions

segments.content: • How in the hell would you fix this?
segments.html: • How in the hell would you fix this?
segments.markdown: - How in the hell would you fix this?

segments.content: • I have some vague ideas, but they're all "hard"
segments.html: • I have some vague ideas, but they're all "hard"
segments.markdown: - I have some vague ideas, but they're all "hard"

segments.content: • Require Python to do its own form of thread scheduling (or at least cooperate with the OS)
segments.html: • Require Python to do its own form of thread scheduling (or at least cooperate with the OS)
segments.markdown: - Require Python to do its own form of thread scheduling (or at least cooperate with the OS)

segments.content: • Would involve a non-trivial interaction between the interpreter implementation, the operating system scheduler, the thread library, and C extension modules (egad!)
segments.html: • Would involve a non-trivial interaction between the interpreter implementation, the operating system scheduler, the thread library, and C extension modules (egad!)
segments.markdown: - Would involve a non-trivial interaction between the interpreter implementation, the operating system scheduler, the thread library, and C extension modules (egad!)

segments.content: Is it Worth It? If you could fix it, it wouldmake thread execution (evenwith theGlL)more predictable andlessresourceintensive Might improve performance/responsiveness of applications that have a mix of CPU and I/O- boundprocessing Probably good for libraries that use threads in the background (e.g.,multiprocessing) Might be able to do it without rewriting the wholeinterpreter. 45
